noteParagraph.text: Alkali metals: Li, Na, K, Rb, Cs, Fr
Alkaline earth metals: Ca, Sr, Ba, Ra
Lanthanides: elements with atomic numbers 57 to 71 inclusive
Actinides: elements with atomic numbers 89 to 103 inclusive
Refractory metals: Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta, W
Halogens: F, Cl, Br, I, At
Noble gases: He, Ne, Ar, Kr, Xe, Rn
Platinum group: Os, Ir, Pt, Ru, Rh, Pd
Noble metals: Ag, Au, Platinum group
Light metals: alkali metals, alkaline earth metals, Be, Al, Mg
Heavy metals: metals other than light metals
Non-metals: H, B, C, Si, N, P, O, S, Se, Te, noble gases, halogens
Transition elements: elements with atomic numbers 21 to 30 inclusive, 39 to 48 inclusive, 57 to 80 inclusive, 89 upwards

titlePart.entryReference: obtaining metal compounds from mixtures, e.g. ores, which are intermediate compounds in a metallurgical process for obtaining a free metal ,
production of non-metallic elements or inorganic compounds by electrolysis or electrophoresis

noteParagraph.text: In the absence of an indication to the contrary, a compound is classified in the last appropriate place within this class.
Attention is drawn to the definitions of groups of chemical elements following the title of Section C.

titlePart.text: Separation of hydrogen from mixtures containing it
titlePart.entryReference: separation of gases by physical means
production of water-gas and synthesis gas from solid carbonaceous material
purifying or modifying the chemical compositions of combustible technical gases containing carbon monoxide

titlePart.text: Production of hydrogen or of gaseous mixtures containing hydrogen
by decomposition of inorganic compounds, e.g. ammonia
by reaction of inorganic compounds containing electro-positively bound hydrogen, e.g. water, acids, bases, ammonia, with inorganic reducing agents
by reaction of water vapour with metals
by reaction of water vapour with carbon monoxide
by reaction of metal hydroxides with carbon monoxide
by decomposition of gaseous or liquid organic compounds
by reaction of gaseous or liquid organic compounds with gasifying agents, e.g. water, carbon dioxide, air
by reaction of hydrocarbons with gasifying agents
using oxygen or mixtures containing oxygen as gasifying agents
using discontinuously preheated non-moving solid materials, e.g. blast and run
followed by reaction of water vapour with carbon monoxide
Separation of hydrogen or hydrogen containing gases from gaseous mixtures, e.g. purification

Inorganic compounds thereof prepared by isotope exchange, e.g. NH3+D2
NH2D+HD
titlePart.entryReference: other chemical reactions to form compounds of hydrogen isotopes, see the relevant groups for hydrogen compounds in class

titlePart.text: Preparation by chemical reaction of hydrogen isotopes or their compounds, e.g. 4ND3+7O2 4NO2+6D2O, 2D2+O2 2D2O

titlePart.entryReference: higher hydrides of boron, substituted hydrides of boron

titlePart.text: Hydrides of alkali metals, alkaline earth metals, beryllium or magnesium
Hydrides of aluminium, gallium, indium, thallium, germanium, tin, lead, arsenic, antimony, bismuth or polonium
Preparation from boron or inorganic compounds containing boron and oxygen
Addition complexes of monoborane or diborane, e.g. with phosphine, arsine or hydrazine
Preparation from boron or inorganic compounds containing boron and oxygen
Preparation from other compounds of boron
Preparation of boranates of alkali metals, alkaline earth metals, magnesium or beryllium
Addition complexes thereof, e.g. LiBH4.2N2H4, NaB2H7
Preparation of boranates of other metals, e.g. aluminium borohydride
Hydrides containing at least two metals, e.g. Li(AlH4)
Preparation from the metal with the highest valency or from its oxides or salts of its oxyacids
Preparation of chlorine from hydrogen chloride

titlePart.entryReference: particular individual halides, see the relevant groups in sub-classes according to the element combined with the halogen

titlePart.text: from air with the aid of metal oxides, e.g. barium oxide, manganese oxide
Methods for preparing oxides or hydroxides in general
titlePart.entryReference: particular individual oxides or hydroxides, see the relevant groups of sub-classes or , according to the element combined with the oxygen or hydroxyl

titlePart.text: by thermal decomposition of compounds, e.g. of salts or hydroxides
by oxidation of elements in the gaseous state
by oxidation or hydrolysis of compounds in the gaseous state
in the presence of hot combustion gases
in the presence of a fluidised bed
using a plasma or an electric discharge
Removal and cooling of the oxide containing suspension
by oxidation or hydrolysis of elements or compounds in the liquid or solid state
by oxidation or hydrolysis of sprayed or atomised solutions
Anhydrous solutions or gaseous mixtures containing hydrogen peroxide
Preparation from inorganic peroxy-compounds, e.g. from peroxysulphates
of alkali metals, alkaline earth metals or of magnesium
Recovery of sulphur from material containing elemental sulphur, e.g. luxmasses
from gaseous sulphur compounds including gaseous sulphides
from non-gaseous sulphides or materials containing such sulphides, e.g. ores
Finely-divided sulphur, e.g. sublimed sulphur, flowers of sulphur
Methods for preparing sulphides or polysulphides, in general
titlePart.entryReference: sulphides or polysulphides of metals, other than alkali metals, magnesium, calcium, strontium, and barium, see the relevant groups of sub-classes or according to the metal

titlePart.text: Preparation from sodium or potassium amalgam with sulphur or sulphides
Sulphides or polysulphides of magnesium, calcium, strontium, or barium
from oxides or hydroxides with sulphur or hydrogen sulphide
Compounds containing sulphur and halogen, with or without oxygen
Compounds containing sulphur, halogen, hydrogen, and oxygen
Recovery of sulphur dioxide from acid tar and the like
Isolation of sulphur dioxide from gases
Methods of preparing sulphites in general
titlePart.entryReference: particular individual sulphites, see the relevant groups of sub-classes according to the cation

titlePart.text: Liquid phase contacting processes or wet catalysis processes
of sulphuric acid using a nitrogen oxide process
Recovery from acid tar and the like
Methods for the preparation of sulphates in general
titlePart.entryReference: particular individual sulphates, see the relevant groups of sub-classes according to the cation

titlePart.text: Other compounds containing sulphur and oxygen
Binary compounds of nitrogen with metals, with silicon, or with boron
containing one or more halogen atoms
containing also one or more oxygen atoms, e.g. nitrosyl halides
containing one or more sulphur atoms
containing one or more hydrogen atoms
containing also one or more halogen atoms
containing also one or more metal atoms
containing also one or more sulphur atoms
Preparation by catalytic oxidation of ammonia
Preparation by absorption of oxides of nitrogen
Methods for the preparation of nitrates in general
titlePart.entryReference: particular individual nitrates, see the relevant groups of sub-classes according to the cation

titlePart.text: Treating phosphate ores or other raw phosphate materials to obtain phosphorus or phosphorus compounds
Sulphur, selenium, or tellurium compounds of phosphorus
Preparation from elemental phosphorus or phosphoric anhydride
Preparation by reacting phosphate containing material with an acid, e.g. wet process
with sulphuric acid, a mixture of acids mainly consisting of sulphuric acid or a mixture of compounds forming it in situ, e.g. a mixture of sulphur dioxide, water and oxygen
only one form of calcium sulphate being formed
one form of calcium sulphate being formed and then converted to another form
Preparation by reacting phosphate containing material with concentrated sulphuric acid and subsequently lixiviating the obtained mass, e.g. clincker process
Stabilisation to prevent post-precipitation of dissolved impurities
Phosphates of magnesium, calcium, strontium, or barium
containing plural metal, or metal and ammonium

titlePart.entryReference: by using ultra-high pressure, e.g. for the formation of diamonds,

titlePart.text: Preparation by using gaseous activating agents
Preparation by using non-gaseous activating agents
Preparation of ion-exchanging materials from carbonaceous material
Methods for the preparation of carbonates or bicarbonates in general
titlePart.entryReference: particular individual carbonates, see the relevant groups of sub-classes according to the cation

titlePart.text: Compounds containing carbon and sulphur, e.g. carbon disulphide, carbon oxysulphide

titlePart.entryReference: forming a single crystal layer from the vapour phase

titlePart.text: Compounds containing silicon, fluorine, and other elements
Hydrates thereof, e.g. lepidoic silicic acid
Colloidal silica, e.g. dispersions, gels, sols
Preparation of hydrosols or aqueous dispersions
Preparation of hydroorganosols, organosols or dispersions in an organic medium

titlePart.entryReference: preparation of hydroorganosols, organosols or dispersions in an organic medium from hydrosols

titlePart.text: by progressively adding a sol to a different sol, i.e. "build up" of particles using a "heel"
by acidic treatment of aqueous silicate solutions
Preparation of finely divided silica neither in sol nor in gel form

titlePart.entryReference: preparation of aerogels by dehydrating gels
treatment to enhance the pigmenting or filling properties
monoborane, diborane, metal boranates or addition complexes thereof

titlePart.text: Compounds containing boron and nitrogen, phosphorus, oxygen, sulphur, selenium or tellurium
Compounds containing boron and nitrogen, phosphorus, sulphur, selenium or tellurium
Compounds containing direct bonding between two boron atoms, e.g. Cl2BBCl2
Compounds containing three or more boron atoms, e.g. Na B3H8, MgB10Br10
